text: If this is something you end up doing frequently, and with different operations, you should probably create a class to handle cases like this, or better use some library like Numpy.
Otherwise, look for list comprehensions used with the zip builtin function:

code: [a - b for a, b in zip(a, b)]

text: Here's an alternative to list comprehensions.
Map iterates through the list(s) (the latter arguments), doing so simulataneously, and passes their elements as arguments to the function (the first arg).
It returns the resulting list.
This code because has less syntax (which is more aesthetic for me), and apparently it's 40% faster for lists of length 5 (see bobince's comment).
Still, either solution will work.

If you plan on performing more than simple one liners, it would be better to implement your own class and override the appropriate operators as they apply to your case.
Taken from Mathematics in Python:

code:
class Vector:

  def __init__(self, data):
    self.data = data

  def __repr__(self):
    return repr(self.data)  

  def __add__(self, other):
    data = []
    for j in range(len(self.data)):
      data.append(self.data[j] + other.data[j])
    return Vector(data)  

x = Vector([1, 2, 3])    
print x + x

A slightly different Vector class.

code:
class Vector( object ):
    def __init__(self, *data):
        self.data = data
    def __repr__(self):
        return repr(self.data) 
    def __add__(self, other):
        return tuple( (a+b for a,b in zip(self.data, other.data) ) )  
    def __sub__(self, other):
        return tuple( (a-b for a,b in zip(self.data, other.data) ) )
